perturbation.original_text: The Company shall return to the Repairer's facilities indicated in Clause 6 ("Deliveries") any Core Unit with the Work Order form ref 7-3 duly filled-in, as standard exchange counterparts, within a maximum [*****] as from the Delivery Date of the LRU from the Pool for any Items from the list A of the Exhibit 6 ("LRUs covered by repair and standard exchange services") and within a maximum of [*****] as from the Delivery Date of the LRU from the Pool for any Items from the list B of the Exhibit 6 ("LRUs covered by repair and standard exchange services").
perturbation.changed_text: The Company should endeavor to return Core Units to the Repairer’s facilities indicated in Clause 6 ("Deliveries") with a Work Order form ref 7-3, as standard exchange counterparts, within a reasonable timeframe as from the Delivery Date of the LRU from the Pool.
perturbation.explanation: Replacing 'shall return' with 'should endeavor to return' makes the obligation non-mandatory. The phrase 'reasonable timeframe' lacks a specific deadline, making enforcement difficult. This creates an ambiguous legal obligation.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Brazilian Civil Aviation Regulations - specifically those pertaining to mandatory maintenance schedules and return of components for traceability purposes - R CBA.
perturbation.location: EXHIBIT 9 - SPARE PARTS STANDARD EXCHANGE SERVICE - Section 4.1

perturbation.original_text: In such case, the Company shall return to the Repairer such unserviceable Item removed from the Aircraft with a Work Order for repair in the form set out in Exhibit 7-2 within [*****] from the withdrawal of the corresponding Item from the Stock.
perturbation.changed_text: In such cases, the Company may attempt to return such unserviceable Item removed from the Aircraft with a Work Order for repair in a generally timely fashion.
perturbation.explanation: The original text stipulates a clear obligation to return unserviceable items within a specified timeframe. The change weakens this obligation by using 'may attempt,' which is discretionary, and 'generally timely fashion,' which is vague. This introduces ambiguity regarding the mandatory nature and timing of the return.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Brazilian Aviation Regulations (RBAC 145) that emphasize the need for timely repair of defective components of the aircraft to ensure safety.
perturbation.location: EXHIBIT 8 - LEASE OF THE STOCK - Section 5

perturbation.original_text: The Repairer shall provide the Company with a Main Elements' maintenance (as per Clause 2 of this Exhibit 11) and availability (as per Clause 3 of this Exhibit 11) Service.
perturbation.changed_text: The Repairer will aim to provide, when reasonably possible, a Main Elements' maintenance (as per Clause 2 of this Exhibit 11) and availability (as per Clause 3 of this Exhibit 11) Service.
perturbation.explanation: The original text uses “shall provide”, indicating a mandatory obligation. The modified text uses 'will aim to provide' and 'when reasonably possible' making the obligation discretionary and contingent. This change weakens the Repairer’s commitment and introduces ambiguity.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Brazilian Civil Aviation Authority (ANAC) regulations related to aircraft maintenance programs (IS 43-002), which require clear and mandatory maintenance obligations to ensure airworthiness.
